Trailer: Atomic Blonde
An undercover MI6 agent is sent to Berlin during the Cold War to investigate the murder of a fellow agent and recover a missing list of double agents.
David Leitch's Atomic Blonde, based on the graphic novel The Coldest City, injects some serious glamour into a big Hollywood movie. This is a film where glamour is the whole point, albeit glamour of a paradoxical, hardboiled kind. Charlize Theron plays the blonde of the title, MI6 operative Lorraine Broughton, who arrives in West Berlin at the end of the Cold War on a mission about a stolen piece of microfilm and a fellow agent (James McAvoy) gone rogue. The details of the plot don't matter; what counts is the vibe. Leitch grooves on everything about this setting - the cloudy skies, the lounging punks, the graffiti on the Berlin Wall, and the absence of digital technology that makes the whole world somehow more immediate than the one we know today. This immediacy is a mixed blessing for Lorraine and the other spies, who are often subjected to spectacularly brutal violence. The fight scenes are in the neo-classical manner of John Wick, which Leitch co-directed with Chad Stahelski. In these scenes the camera stays distant enough to let us appreciate the stunt work, yet still seems caught up in the action, as if it were an obstacle the characters could collide with at any moment. The film resembles an advertisement, and sometimes literally is one, with Lorraine showing a decided fondness for a certain brand of vodka. It's also a lot like a fashion shoot, Theron looking like a rock'n'roll ice princess in the tradition of Nico and Debbie Harry; other free-associative cultural allusions range from the Queen and Bowie songs on the soundtrack to a clip from the Russian science fiction classic Stalker. This reliance on quotation helps explain why Atomic Blonde lacks the gravity and melancholy a director like Michael Mann can achieve in an equally abstract genre context. The casual yet explicit treatment of Lorraine's love affair with another woman (Sofia Boutella) is something new in American pop culture, but this relationship is never as emotionally central as it should be. Similarly, the ending feels as if Leitch shot three or four options, then picked the safest and least interesting. But none of this can take away the fact that in between this film and Mad Max: Fury Road, Theron has become one of the major action stars of world cinema. Again, her appeal depends on a paradox, which the whole film is built around: her ability to seem at once coolly unreachable and physically vulnerable. The vulnerability registers in tiny but crucial moments, like the hoarse, pained cough she gives when lying prone on the floor - not a sound you'd be likely to hear from James Bond, but one you or I might well emit if we suffered a fraction of the damage Lorraine does here.
